This means that when one is mentioned, all three are included; when the three are spoken of, their essence is one. It is not sequential, parallel, or separate, and is called the Secret Treasury. This is the true earth element.

The two lines below pure describe the extent of its virtues. It is called pure because it corresponds with no falsity and is endowed with the dharmas of no-outflows. It is called naturally luminous because it is not conditioned. It is called all-pervading because it is omnipresent.

If one understands this dharma, one accomplishes the three wondrous contemplations. Second, citing examples to extensively refute, two parts:

Ananda, if the sun came, it would be able to burn the moxa in your hand, and the forests and trees where it came from would all be burned.

This refutes the moxa giving rise to fire.

This concludes that there is no source.

If it were produced from causes and conditions, it would be present here but absent there, and it would be present now but not present in the future. When conditions come together, it arises. When conditions separate, it ceases.
This is not so now. The original repository of the Tathagata is originally all-pervading, and it has never moved or shaken. Therefore, it is called great.

All of them are called great because they are all-pervading, because they do not move or shake, because they are the true merits within the repository nature, and because their great functions are everywhere and benefit all places. You do not fully understand that within the TathÄgata's treasury, the nature of awakened awareness is the true void, and the nature of void is the true awakened awareness. It is pure, originally so, and pervades the Dharma realm, responding to the cognitive capacities of sentient beings according to their minds.
Ä€nanda!
Just as the void of a single well gives rise to the void of a single well, the ten directions of space are also like this, perfectly filling the ten directions. How can there be any fixed location?
It manifests in accordance with karmic activity.
The analogy can be understood as before.
Fourth, concluding by reproaching deluded emotions.
The ignorant in the world mistake causes and conditions and natural natures, all of which are distinctions and calculations of the discriminating mind. There are only words, but no real meaning.
The nature of the six sense organs is also like this.
The Hinayana often discusses the four great elements, and the Mahayana teachings begin to have the name of emptiness.

The sense organs and consciousnesses that are called great have not been seen in the sutras. In the perfect and true teachings, the perfect contemplation of all dharmas, the three of sense organs, sense objects, and consciousnesses are all-pervading and unmoving. Although there is this meaning, the name great is not established.
Now this is specially brought out, truly the final ultimate model.
The text has four parts:
First, generally indicating the absence of nature.
Ä€nanda!
Seeing and awareness are without knowledge, they exist due to form and emptiness.
Second, citing examples to extensively refute, two:
First, citing examples to indicate the thesis.

Now, as you are in the Jeta Grove, in the morning it is bright, in the evening it is dark. Even in the middle of the night, when there is a full moon it is bright, when it is a dark night it is dark. Then brightness and darkness are analyzed based on seeing.
Does this seeing have the same essence as brightness, darkness, and the vast sky?
Or does it not have the same essence?
Or is it the same and not the same?
Or is it different and not different?
This uses the four propositions to investigate.
That is, is it the same?
Is it different?
Is it both the same and different?
Is it neither the same nor different?
Second, relying on principle to refute.
Ä€nanda!

If this seeing has the same essence as brightness, darkness, and the vast sky, then the two essences of brightness and darkness would be mutually negated. In darkness there is no brightness, in brightness there is no darkness;
if it is the same as darkness, then brightness would be lost to sight;
if it is definitely the same as brightness, then in darkness it should cease to exist. If it ceases to exist, how can it see brightness and darkness?
If light and darkness are distinct, then seeing has no arising or ceasing. How can it be one?
This refutes oneness.
The first four lines summarize the theory, then the next four lines establish the principle, and the next six lines analyze the error.
If seeing and objects are one, then when the object ceases, the seeing perishes. How can one distinguish light from darkness?
The next three lines conclude that it is not so. Light and darkness are distinct, and seeing does not cease accordingly. One should know that this seeing is not the same as objects.
If this seeing essence is not of the same essence as darkness and light, then apart from light, darkness, and empty space, analyzing the source of seeing, what form and appearance does it have?

Apart from light, apart from darkness, and apart from empty space, this seeing source is the same as a turtle's hair and a rabbit's horns. Light, darkness, and empty space are all different. From what is seeing established?
This refutes difference.

The first three sentences summarize the argument. If you separate from... is the main refutation, asking how there can be a form apart from the object. If you separate from brightness... is the conclusion that ultimately there is no substance.
The above is the direct refutation. Brightness and darkness... is the conclusion of the refutation, which can be understood.
Brightness and darkness are mutually exclusive, how can they be the same?
Apart from the three, there is originally nothing, how can they be different?
This refutes both being the same and different.
Same means one. Brightness and darkness are mutually exclusive, so they are called mutually exclusive. If they were the same as the seeing, then they would be extinguished together, as refuted above.
Apart from brightness, darkness, and space, there is no seeing, and being different is also impossible.
Space and seeing are originally boundless, how can they not be the same?
Seeing darkness and seeing brightness are not changing, how can they not be different?
This refutes both not being the same and not being different.
Space and seeing are indistinguishable, so they are not not the same.
Brightness and darkness change by themselves, while seeing has no arising or ceasing, so they are not not different.

You should further examine it carefully, examine it in great detail, examine it thoroughly, and observe clearly that light comes from the sun, darkness follows the moon, openings belong to empty space, and blockages return to the great earth. In this way, from which of these four conditions does the seeing essence arise?
This is the second time of questioning.
It encourages careful examination of which of the four conditions gives rise to seeing.
Seeing and awareness are empty and dull, not combined or united. It should not be the case that the seeing essence arises from nothing.
This refutes the view that there is no cause for combination and union.
Third, reconciling with the true meaning, in three parts:
First, classifying and connecting with the previous meaning.
If the nature of seeing, hearing, and knowing is perfectly all-pervading and originally unmoving,

you should know that boundless, unmoving empty space, and the moving earth, water, fire, and wind are all called the six great elements. Their nature is truly perfectly integrated, all the matrix of the tathÄgata, originally unborn and unceasing.
The reason why seeing, hearing, awareness, and knowing are all called great elements is because they are constant and pervasive, as explained in the previous text.
Second, reprimanding and encouraging careful investigation.
Ä€nanda!
Your nature is sinking and drowning, not understanding that your seeing, hearing, awareness, and knowing are originally the TathÄgata's treasury.
You should observe this seeing, hearing, awareness, and knowing, is it arising or ceasing?
Is it the same or different?
Is it neither arising nor ceasing?
Is it neither the same nor different?
Arising and ceasing is the same.
Not arising or ceasing is different.
Being the same or different is both.
Since seeing and hearing are true, the four statements cannot be obtained. Unmoving and all-pervading, how great it is!
Third, directly reconciling with the present principle.

You have never known that within the TathÄgata's treasury, the nature of seeing is the clarity of awareness, the essence of awareness is the clear seeing, pure and originally thus, pervading the Dharma realm, responding to the cognitive capacity of sentient beings according to their minds.

Just as the seeing faculty sees throughout the Dharma realm, hearing, smelling, tasting, touching, seeing, touching, and knowing all have wondrous virtues that are clear and distinct, pervading the Dharma realm, and filling the ten directions. How could they have a specific location?
They appear in accordance with karmic activity.
Zeng means then.
As for hearing, smelling, tasting, and touching, the two faculties of the nose and tongue only become aware when the object is present, so they are called tasting and touching.
Touching is the body.
Knowing is the mind.
Fourth, concluding by reprimanding deluded emotions.

The ignorant in the world are confused by causes and conditions and the nature of spontaneity. These are all distinctions and calculations made by the discriminating mind. They are just words and have no real meaning.
Seventh, the nature of consciousness, in four parts:
First, generally indicating the absence of nature.
Ä€nanda!
The nature of consciousness has no source and arises from the six sense faculties and sense objects in delusion.
Second, citing examples to refute in detail, in two parts:
First, citing examples to indicate and investigate.
Now, look all around this assembly of sages. As your eyes move about, it is like a mirror reflecting things without any separate analysis.
Your consciousness, in sequence, points to each one, saying, 'This is Manjushri, this is Purna, this is Maudgalyayana, this is Subhuti, this is Shariputra.'
Does this consciousness that discerns arise from seeing?
Does it arise from form?
Does it arise from empty space?
Or does it arise without any cause, suddenly appearing on its own?
The faculties can illuminate objects, like a mirror reflecting things.
Consciousness can discern objects and distinguish self and other.
From what does this consciousness arise?
Second, reasoning is used to refute.
Ananda!
If your consciousness arises from seeing, then without light, darkness, and form and space, these four would necessarily be nonexistent, and you would have no seeing.
If the nature of seeing does not exist, how can consciousness arise from it?
This refutes the idea that consciousness arises from the faculties.
With form and seeing, form without seeing, the faculties are still formless, from what do the consciousnesses arise?
If your consciousness arises from form and not from seeing, not seeing light and not seeing darkness, light and darkness not seen, then there is no form or space;
that form is still nonexistent, from what does consciousness arise?
This refutes the objective realm.
Form and seeing depend on each other, without seeing there is no form;
form is still not established, from what can there be consciousness?
If it arises from space, not form, not seeing, without seeing there is no discernment, it cannot know light, darkness, form, or space by itself;
not form, it cannot serve as the condition for cessation, seeing, hearing, awareness, and knowing have no place to be established.
This refutes the claim that consciousness arises from space.
The first two lines examine and determine that it does not arise from faculties or objects.
Without seeing... and below directly refutes, the first three lines refute the claim that without seeing there is no discernment of the four objects.
Not form... and below, the three lines refute the claim that without form the five faculties are not established.
The characteristics are the conditions. Since the four objects do not exist, the perceived objects cease;
Since the perceived objects do not exist, how can the five sense faculties exist?
The above all refutes the need for sense faculties and objects.
Dwelling in this non-duality, emptiness is the same as nonexistence;
Existence is not the same as objects. Even if your consciousness arises, what can it discriminate?
This directly refutes the idea that consciousness arises from emptiness.
Non-characteristics and non-seeing are called non-duality, which directly points to emptiness.
The same as nonexistence means like a turtle's hair or a rabbit's horns, which are ultimately nonexistent.
If it is said that emptiness has substance, how can it be the same as objects that have form and appearance?

Moreover, this empty space is dark and pure without discrimination. If the undifferentiated emptiness gives rise to something, it should also be undifferentiated. Therefore, it is said, What can it discriminate?
If it arises without a cause, suddenly appearing, why do you not perceive the bright moon in the daytime?
This refutes the idea of no cause.
Without the moon in the middle of the day, since there is no consciousness of seeing the moon, you should know that it is not without a cause.

You should further carefully examine, examine in detail, the seeing relies on your eyes, the characteristics push the external objects, if they can form an appearance it is existent, if they cannot form an appearance it is non-existent, in this way, what is the cause of the consciousness?
The moving consciousness and the still seeing are neither combined nor united.
This is a second examination of the place of arising.
Clear refers to the floating dust, objects refers to light and dark, forming existence and non-existence refers to space.
The two sentences below moving consciousness conclude that they are neither combined nor united. Moving refers to being able to discriminate, still refers to merely illuminating objects.
Hearing, smelling, touching, and knowing are also like this. The conditions for consciousness should not arise without a cause.
The first two sentences give an example to refute the other consciousnesses.
Hearing and smelling refer to the ears and nose, touching and knowing refer to the tongue, body, and mental consciousnesses.
The last two sentences conclude that there is no place of arising. Since the arising of consciousness is due to conditions, it is called the conditions for consciousness.
Third, reconciling with the true meaning, in three parts:
First, classifying and connecting with the previous meaning.

If this mind-consciousness originally comes from nowhere, you should know that the perfect and tranquil nature of the discriminating seeing, hearing, awareness, and knowing does not come from anything.

Together with empty space, earth, water, fire, and wind, they are collectively called the seven great elements. Their nature is truly perfect and inclusive, all being the matrix of the tathÄgata, originally unborn and unceasing.
The first two sentences are the classification, and you should know below is what is classified.
Discriminating refers to consciousness, and seeing, hearing refers to the faculties, which are the faculties that give rise to consciousness, hence it says discriminating seeing, hearing, etc.
Second, reprimanding and encouraging careful investigation.
Ä€nanda!
Your mind is coarse and floating, not understanding that seeing, hearing, and the fundamentally illuminating awareness are the matrix of the tathÄgata.
You should observe this consciousness of the six sense bases - is it the same or different?
Is it empty or existent?
Is it neither the same nor different, neither empty nor existent?
The same and different are as refuted in the faculties.
Empty refers to emptiness arising, existent refers to faculties and objects, and neither empty nor existent means without cause.
Third, directly reconciling with the present principle.

You have fundamentally not known that within the TathÄgatagarbha, the nature of consciousness is luminous knowing, the luminous knowing is true consciousness, the wondrous enlightenment is tranquil, pervading and encompassing the Dharma realm, containing and exhaling the ten directions. How could there be a specific location?
It manifests in accordance with karmic activity.
Fourth, concluding by reproaching deluded emotions.

The ignorant in the world are confused by causes and conditions and the nature of spontaneity. All of this is the discriminating thoughts of the conscious mind. There are only words, but no true meaning.
Third, following the previous revelation and attaining enlightenment, there are two parts:
First, fully narrating the assembly's understanding, there are two parts:
First, briefly narrating the removal of doubts.
At that time, Ä€nanda and the great assembly, having received the subtle revelation of the Buddha TathÄgata, their bodies and minds were completely at ease, free from obstruction.

The three categories and seven great elements are both phenomena and nature, originally unborn, now without cessation, birth, cessation, coming, and going are all the TathÄgata's treasury, perfectly pervasive, unmoving, pure, and originally thus. This is what the TathÄgata proclaims as the true nature of ultimate meaning within supreme meaning, thus it is said to be subtly revealed.
Body and mind are perfectly clear, thus it is said to be utterly clear.
There are no more dharmas that can be doubted, thus there are no hindrances.
Second, extensively describing the benefits obtained, there are four:
First, the benefit of realizing the vast mind.
This great assembly each and every one knows their mind pervades the ten directions, seeing the empty space of the ten directions like holding a leaf in their hand.
Previously they grasped the mind as being within the body, thinking it to be their true nature.
Now they know the emptiness is within the mind, like holding a piece of something in the palm of the hand.
The text below also says, Emptiness arises within great enlightenment, like a single bubble on the ocean.
Second, the benefit of understanding all things are true.
All existing things in the world are the wondrous, bright, fundamental mind of bodhi. The essence of the mind is all-pervading and perfect, encompassing the ten directions.
Previously, it was grasped that there are dharmas outside the mind. Now, it is realized that every dharma is only mind.
Apart from the true nature, no dharma can be obtained. Therefore, all things in the world are bodhi.
Bodhi means enlightenment, and enlightenment is Buddha. If one insists that insentient beings do not have Buddha-nature, please look at this text.
Even if one believes that insentient beings have Buddha-nature, it is still said that they do not possess all dharmas, which then causes the Buddha-nature to be divided into two:
1. Buddha-nature possessing all dharmas, referring to the nature of sentient beings;
2. Buddha-nature not possessing all dharmas, referring to the nature of insentient beings.
If this division is made, how is it different from the statement that insentient grasses and trees do not have Buddha-nature?
Now, a syllogism is presented:
All grasses and trees are the subject, definitely possessing all dharmas is the thesis, the reason is because they have Buddha-nature, the example is like sentient beings.
The correct teaching is stated:

Earth, water, fire, and wind are all called the seven great elements. Their nature is true, perfect, and interfused, all being the matrix of the tathÄgata. The wondrous enlightenment is tranquil and still, pervading the entire Dharma realm, containing and exhaling the ten directions. How could there be any fixed location?
Those who receive and uphold this teaching should carefully examine it.
Third, the benefit of turning back and abandoning the physical body.

Looking back at the body born from one's parents, it is like a tiny speck of dust blown in the ten directions of empty space, sometimes present, sometimes gone. It is like a single floating bubble in the vast ocean, arising and ceasing without origin.
The vast sky occupies my mind, yet it is still like a small object in the palm. Looking further at the tiny substance born from me, how big or small is it in the mind?
Therefore, raising a speck of dust in the sky, its presence or absence cannot be discerned, using this as a metaphor for the utmost minuteness.
Like the tranquil... again raising a bubble as a metaphor, illustrating that the body has no origin.
The previous metaphor still retains a small appearance, while this metaphor illustrates that the appearance is originally unborn. Therefore, these two metaphors each manifest one meaning.
Fourth, the benefit of wondrously attaining the fundamental mind.
Clearly and distinctly knowing, one attains the wondrous fundamental mind, eternally abiding and indestructible.
Clearly means to manifest, as if it were distinct.
Distinctly is a word of expression.
Since the understanding is in the mind, it is said to be self-knowing.
Attain means to obtain. Being deluded and mistaken is called loss, while understanding and awakening is called attainment.
Since it is said to be eternally abiding and indestructible, it is not newly obtained, but only manifested.
Second, Ä€nanda speaks a verse in praise, in two parts:
First, the introduction.
Bowing to the Buddha with palms joined, having experienced something unprecedented, he spoke a verse in praise of the Buddha in front of the TathÄgata:
Having benefited in his mind, he was able to receive the revelation, so he extended his reverence and expressed praise, recounting the benefits and giving rise to the aspiration.
Second, the main discourse, in four parts:
First, praising the Buddha's Dharma as rare, in two parts:
First, the actual praise.

The first line praises the Buddha.
The Buddha has three bodies, namely the Dharma body, the retribution body, and the response body. Now all are praised in summary.

The essence of the Buddha is immovable, without any intention. It is like the moon not descending and the hundred waters not ascending. The power of the roots of goodness of compassion is naturally like this. It is also like a mirror image appearing according to the form. Moreover, wonderful and honorable are both general terms for the upper and lower [parts of the text], referring to the three bodies being one essence, not three yet three, with essence, characteristics, function, and all meanings complete, thus called wonderful;

The previous line is about principle and fruition, the next line is about practice. Principle, fruition, and practice are the meanings to be expounded. They must be revealed through both the expounder and the expounded. Therefore, all four dharmas are praised.
Second, the benefits are described.
Destroying my inverted thoughts from hundreds of millions of kalpas, without going through eons, I attain the Dharma body.
The first line is the elimination of hindrances, which is the previous body and mind are at ease, without obstruction.
The next sÅ«tra says, From beginningless time, inverted and deluded.
Now, hundreds of millions is just a rough estimate.

Mistakenly taking the four elements and the reflections of the six sense objects as the characteristics of body and mind, deluded about one's own nature and regarding it as external objects, whether contemplating the great or the small, are all inverted and false deluded thoughts.
Now, hearing the revelation, not grasping or clinging to them, is called dissolving.
The next line is about realizing the Way, which is attaining the wondrous fundamental mind that is eternally abiding and indestructible.
Asamkhyeya means innumerable.
Kalpa means a period of time.
The expedient teachings say that all Buddhas cultivated the perfections for innumerable kalpas before becoming Buddhas.
Now, in this assembly, they suddenly realize and attain the wondrous fundamental mind that is eternally abiding and indestructible, so how can there be any passing through asamkhyeya kalpas?
Therefore, the text below says, Cessation is enlightenment, not obtained from others. Why rely on exhausting effort to cultivate and realize?
It also says, With a snap of the fingers, one transcends the stage of no more learning.
The Perfect Enlightenment Sutra says, Knowing the illusion is already liberation, without needing any expedient means;
Separating from illusion is precisely enlightenment, and there is also no gradual sequence.
All of these are the meaning of this text.

However, based on the present text, it first describes understanding and enlightenment. As the text says, Each of them knows for themselves that their minds pervade the ten directions. Knowing is understanding. Although the description discusses understanding, it is not without realization and enlightenment, because the level of entry into the stages varies for different people.

For example, the two vehicles of the two teachings, the bodhisattvas who receive the provisional teachings, and those with the potential for the perfect teachings who have not yet given rise to faith, understand this realm, which is understanding through understanding.
If they have already entered the stages of faith, understanding, and practice, and hear the Dharma to open their understanding, then it is realization through realization.
There are also those who have already entered the stages and grounds, and thus increase their understanding and reduce their afflictions.

Up to the stage of wondrous enlightenment, they destroy delusions and realize the truth, giving rise to wondrous and true functions, all discussed in terms of the shallow and deep levels of the stages.
This means that the assembly at the meeting all obtained wondrous benefits.
Second, vowing to attain the fruit and deliver sentient beings, there are two parts:
First, directly expressing the vow, there are two parts:
First, expressing the vow.
May I now attain the fruition and become a precious king, and liberate such an infinite number of beings.
The first line describes wisdom, which is the vow to accomplish the unsurpassed Buddha Way.
Since it is hoped to attain realization in this very body, it says may I now.
The next line describes compassion, which is the vow to liberate infinite sentient beings.
The line below says to eliminate afflictions, which is the vow to eradicate afflictions without remainder.
Compassion and wisdom are the two dharmas of the bodhi mind, which is precisely the essence of the Way.
Furthermore, the vow is used to comprehensively uphold it, which is the complete three dharmas and the perfect four vows. The generation of the bodhi mind is complete here.
According to the Commentary on Perfect Enlightenment, the initial ground of the sudden teaching generally has three layers:
First, the realization and awakening of the nature of enlightenment, which is the previous attainment of the wondrous fundamental mind and the realization of the Dharma body;
Second, the generation of the bodhi mind, which is the present two vows of compassion and wisdom;
Third, the cultivation of bodhisattva practices, which is the subsequent inquiry into the methods of practice.
If one does not understand one's own mind, how can one know the right path?
Therefore, practicing for many eons is not true bodhisattva practice.

Next, without giving rise to the great mind, there is no way to give rise to practice. Therefore, Sudhana first declares his own giving rise [to the aspiration for enlightenment], and then asks about practice. The perfect and sudden cultivation and realization is none other than this.
Second, expressing the meaning.
With this profound mind, I respectfully serve the Buddha's teachings in the dust-like lands, and this is called repaying the Buddha's kindness.

The upper line is the same as the Buddha's transformation, seeking above and transforming below. The two minds of compassion and wisdom, each first awakens to the wondrous and luminous nature of enlightenment.
Born from this profound principle, it is called the profound mind.
With these two minds, one respectfully follows the Buddha's transformative practices in the dust-like lands, without duality or distinction, and is therefore called respectful service.

The lower line concludes the repayment of kindness. Second, earnestly requesting verification.

My vow to attain enlightenment is originally for the sake of liberating sentient beings. The mind to liberate sentient beings is not for a temporary period. Until the end of the future, until the realm of sentient beings is exhausted, I will then enter nirvana.

Second, requesting to eliminate delusions and quickly attain enlightenment.

Great hero, great strength, great compassion, I hope you will further eliminate subtle delusions, enabling me to quickly attain supreme enlightenment and sit in the Way-place in the worlds of the ten directions.
The first sentence praises the virtues.
With majestic and powerful virtue like a lion king, therefore called hero.
Endowed with ten meanings, unyielding, therefore called strength.
Compassion means to remove suffering and bring happiness.
Having no conditions, universally saving, all called great to show supremacy.
The next sentence requests to eliminate delusions.
The afflictions of one's own vehicle and the knowables of the Great Vehicle are both called subtle.

The two lines below request swift accomplishment. The previous text already vowed to attain the fruit, but now it is mentioned again because the mind of saving beings is urgent and wishes for an early attainment.
The upper line is the true body, and the lower line is the manifestation of response.
To ascend means to accomplish.
The place of enlightenment refers to manifesting the eight appearances.
The previous statement not becoming extinct until becoming discusses time vertically;
Now, in the worlds of the ten directions discusses space horizontally, which explains the seeking above and transforming below.

The nature of Shunyeta can be destroyed, but the Shujialuo mind does not move.
Shunyeta means emptiness.
